fields.question: What is the unit of measurement for household energy?
What is the unit of measurement for power?
What are the two things the sun provides?

fields.answer: Ability to run power meter forwards or backwards
fields.question: What is net metering?

fields.answer: reuse containers, bring your own container, use reusable bags, etc
fields.question: Name one way you can reduce the amount of trash you produce
What concept in electricity is like a car's speedometer?
What concept in electricity is like a car's odometer?

fields.answer: higher prices, climate change, lost beaches
fields.question: What might be some consequences of failing to make changes in Hawaii's current energy generation?

fields.answer: doesn't work at night, or when very cloudy
fields.question: What is one limitation of solar power?

fields.answer: less fresh water, less beach, more drought, more floods, more coral bleaching
fields.question: What is one expected impact of climate change in Hawaii?

fields.answer: reduce it, get it under 350 ppm
fields.question: What should we do about carbon dioxide?

fields.answer: Reduce our energy use, reduce energy footprint
fields.question: How can we in Hawaii reduce our carbon footprint?
How much of Hawaii's energy comes from oil?
What did you learn from the video?

fields.answer: Hale Aloha dorms, or Lehua, Ilima, Mokihana
fields.question: Where is the Kukui Cup taking place?

fields.answer: freshmen, first-year students, residents of Hale Aloha
fields.question: What students can participate?
How much power does a game console use?
How much does power a microwave use?
How much power does a solar panel generate?
How much energy is in a AA battery?
How much energy does a solar panel generate per day?
How much energy does a Hale Aloha tower use per day?
How much does a kilowatt-hour cost in Hawaii?

fields.answer: a power plant that turns some of Hawaii's waste into energy
fields.question: What is H-POWER?
What percentage of our trash does H-POWER convert into energy?
What are the three components of the trash pyramid?
Which device uses the most power: mobile phone, laptop, or hair dryer?

fields.answer: so many types available, easier for renewables to be price competitive here
fields.question: What is one reason renewable power has great potential in Hawaii?
What is the main source of energy in Hawaii?
What is one way to reduce energy use from lighting?
Which light source uses more power, compact fluorescent (CFL) or LED?
Which light source uses more power, incandescent or compact fluorescent (CFL)?

fields.answer: vampire power, devices can use energy when powered off
fields.question: Why would we measure the power drawn by a device that is off?
What are the two ways to "keep score" in the Kukui Cup?
How do you earn raffle tickets?
How many commitments can you have at one time?

fields.answer: no interconnection, small grids, expensive raw materials
fields.question: What is one reason why energy costs more in Hawaii?

fields.description:
Watch this video explaining the difference between power and energy

<object width="471" height="383"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/hBUg7bsR0d0?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/hBUg7bsR0d0?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="383" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch video about Power & Energy
fields.name: Power & Energy

fields.description:
Find an incandescent bulb and replace it with a CFL. If you've already replaced all the incandescent bulbs in your house with CFLs or LEDs, you might have to go hunt for one elsewhere. You should throw away the incandescent bulb, because even though it isn't burned out it is a massive energy hog and you don't want someone using it later.

For verification, please take a single photo showing both the incandescent bulb you replaced and the CFL you installed.
fields.title: Replace incandescent bulb with compact fluorescent (CFL)
fields.name: CFL bulb

fields.description:
<center>![Laptop falling asleep](/site_media/media/gblocks/SleepyMacBookPro-small.png)</center>

Configure your computer and any external monitor to sleep after 20 minutes of inactivity. You can find instructions on enabling sleep functionality at the [EnergySTAR website](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=power_mgt.pr_power_mgt_users).

Once you have changed your settings, please take a screenshot showing the new settings for use in verification:

  * [How to take a screenshot on Windows](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Microsoft-Windows)
  * [How to take a screenshot on Mac OS X](/help/faq/how-screenshot-mac/)
fields.title: Configure your computer to sleep after inactivity
fields.name: Computer Sleep

fields.description:
![Facebook logo](/site_media/media/gblocks/facebook-logo-small.png)
Show support for the Kukui Cup by Liking the Kukui Cup page on Facebook (it will open in a new window). Follow the link, click on the "Like" button, and then back on this page click the "I Did This!" button. You will be prompted for your name on Facebook so we can verify your Like.
fields.title: Like Kukui Cup on Facebook
fields.name: Like Cup

fields.description:
![Twitter logo](/site_media/media/gblocks/twitter-logo-small.png)
If you use Twitter (will open in a new window), tweet a link to the Kukui Cup website "http://kukuicup.manoa.hawaii.edu/" so other folks will learn about the competition. Once you have tweeted, come back to this page and click the "I Did This!" button. You will be prompted for your Twitter username so we can confirm your tweet.
fields.title: Tweet about Kukui Cup
fields.name: Tweet link

fields.description:
![Google+ logo](/site_media/media/gblocks/google-plus-logo.png)
If you have an account on Google's new social network Google+, share the Kukui Cup website there to get the word out about the competition. Go to Google+ (will open in a new window) and click on the small paperclip icon to share a link:
![Share link area](/site_media/media/gblocks/Google-plus-share-link-small.png)
Enter the text "http://kukuicup.manoa.hawaii.edu/" next to the paperclip icon and press the **Add** button. Above that, type something about the Kukui Cup. Make sure this post is set to be shared with the **Public**, and then press the **Share** button. Once you have updated your status, go to your profile and copy the URL which will look something like "https://plus.google.com/" followed by a long number. Then come back to this page and click the "I Did This!" button. You will be prompted for that profile URL so we can see your snazzy public post.
fields.title: Share Kukui Cup link on Google+
fields.name: Share link

fields.description:
This is a followup activity to the energy audit activity. If you haven't performed that activity, do it first and keep your notes around for this activity.

Based on the audit results, make a label for each device in your room that shows the number of watts consumed when on and off, and put it close to the power switch for those devices that have them.

Once you have made the labels take a photo of the devices with their labels on to be used for verification.
fields.title: Label power hogs in your home
fields.name: Power Hogs

fields.description: Use this carbon footprint calculator (it will open in a new window) to estimate the size of your carbon footprint. Record the size of your footprint for verification.
fields.title: Determine carbon footprint using calculator
fields.name: Carbon footprint

fields.description:
If you missed it during your the first login process, watch this video explaining the competition and this website

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/T37kNTkZCrA?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/T37kNTkZCrA?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>

fields.name: Intro video

fields.description:
Watch this video about improving your energy intuition.

<object width="471" height="383"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/E4MLXlUiRv0?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/E4MLXlUiRv0?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="383" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch video on Energy Intuition
fields.name: Energy Intuition

fields.description:
Watch this video that explains how to figure out how much energy your stuff uses.

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/wc_Cfq9sEoY?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/wc_Cfq9sEoY?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>

fields.description:
Watch this video that talks about how we generate our energy in Hawaii, and what the fuss is about.

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/sAClKZPhcPI?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/sAClKZPhcPI?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>

fields.name: Energy Gen 1

fields.depends_on_text: Watch the "How to audit energy" video
fields.description:
<center>![Belkin Conserve Insight meter](/site_media/media/gblocks/Belkin_Insight-crop.jpg)</center>

Borrow a Belkin Conserve Insight meter from your team coordinator, and then check 5 plug-in appliances in your home to see how much power they use when turned on & when turned off. Write down both the on and off values for each device as you check them because you will need that to get your points.
fields.title: Audit energy use in your home
fields.name: Home Energy Audit

fields.description:
Watch this video that explains how we can get energy directly from the sun.

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/zK_cz7A7qVw?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/zK_cz7A7qVw?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch video about solar energy
fields.name: Solar Energy

fields.depends_on_text: Complete 2 activities in Make Watts category
fields.description:
This is an opportunity to really explore the issue of Hawaii's energy generation in more depth. Pick one of the activities below and go do it! Note that these activities will require significantly more effort than normal activities, but they are also worth more points. This task is worth a variable number of points, so the more effort and the higher quality of your result, the more points you will receive.

You can also do this activity with one or more friends to get the **social bonus** points.

  * Make a YouTube video about energy generation
  * Write a letter to the editor about energy generation
  * Write a song about issues related to Hawaii's energy generation
  * Start a blog about energy generation issues
  * Or something else awesome!
fields.title: Advanced energy generation activity
fields.name: Advanced generation

fields.description:
Watch this video talking about climate change and how it will affect Hawaii.

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/wSquej2rFXM?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/wSquej2rFXM?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch a video about climate change
fields.name: Climate change

fields.description:
Events are a big part of the Kukui Cup, we will have an event running most nights during the competition. Due to the logistics of the beta test, we are not holding any actual events for the beta. However, we would like to test out our event system, so we will be holding a virtual event that you can attend just by going to a web page.

On Sunday 8/14 from 9 AM to 9 PM, you can go to this [virtual event web page](/help/faq/virtual-event-info/) page to get your attendance code. Come back here to redeem the code for your points.

You can also try out the social bonus feature. Just enter the email address of another teammate, and if they also redeem their attendance code, you get 10 bonus points. The social bonus will be used to encourage participants to play the Kukui Cup with other people.
fields.title: Attend a "virtual" beta event
fields.name: Virtual Event

fields.depends_on_text: Complete 2 activities in Lights Out! category
fields.description:
This is an opportunity to really explore the issue of lighting in more depth. Pick one of the activities below and go do it! Note that these activities will require significantly more effort than normal activities, but they are also worth more points. This task is worth a variable number of points, so the more effort and the higher quality of your result, the more points you will receive.

You can also do this activity with one or more friends to get the **social bonus** points.

  * Make a YouTube video about lighting
  * Write a letter to the editor about lighting
  * Write a song about lighting issues
  * Start a blog about lighting
fields.title: Advanced lighting activity
fields.name: Advanced lighting

fields.description:
<center>![Dorm bed](/site_media/media/gblocks/dorm-bed.jpg)</center>

Commit to turning off all appliances in your home (computer, TVs, DVD players, game consoles) every night before you go to sleep. Appliances use a significant amount of electricity, so turning them off when you definitely won't be using them (like when you are asleep) will save energy.
fields.title: I will turn off all appliances every night before going to sleep
fields.name: Off b4 bed

fields.description: Commit to turning off the lights when leaving any room.
fields.title: I will turn off the lights when leaving any room
fields.name: Turn off lights

fields.description: Commit to using task lighting (like a desk lamp) instead of overhead room lights when possible. Often overhead lights provide more light than you need, or might not provide the light where you need it. Using a desk lamp will reduce your electricity use while giving you the light you need, where you need it.
fields.title: I will use task lighting instead of overhead lights
fields.name: Task lighting

fields.description:
<center>![Power strip with multiple things plugged in](/site_media/media/gblocks/powerstrip.jpg)</center>

A vampire load is a device that uses power when plugged in, even when it is turned off and not doing anything. Commit to turning off any vampire loads (cell phone charger, iPod charger, game consoles, TVs) using a power strip when you are not using them, thereby saving energy. If you need a power strip, you can buy them at the UH Bookstore, or many other stores (grocery stores, drug stores, etc).
fields.title: I will turn off vampire loads using a power strip
fields.name: Turn off vampires

fields.description: Commit to turning off water at sinks when you aren't actually using the water, such as when brushing your teeth, shaving, applying makeup, etc. Clean water is a valuable resource that shouldn't be wasted. Also pumping water from the ground into a building, heating it, and then treating the used water takes energy, so reducing the amount of water used saves energy.
fields.title: I will turn off water when brushing my teeth or shaving
fields.name: Turn off water

fields.depends_on_text: Complete either Climate change video activity or Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to turning off water when showering except when actively rinsing off soap or shampoo. Clean water is a valuable resource that shouldn't be wasted. Also pumping water from the ground into a building, heating it, and then treating the used water takes energy, so reducing the amount of water used saves energy.
fields.title: I will turn off water when sudsing and scrubbing in shower
fields.name: Water in shower

fields.description:
<center>![Sun coming through window](/site_media/media/gblocks/sun-window.jpg)</center>

Commit to using natural light from windows or outdoors instead of turning on electric lighting. This can mean opening shades instead of turning on the lights, and/or planning your day so that tasks that require light (like reading books) are done during the day.
fields.title: I will use natural light instead of electric lighting
fields.name: Use sunlight

fields.description: Commit to turning off your printer when you aren't actively printing something out. This will reduce electricity use, since printers draw some power if they are turned on even when they aren't printing.
fields.title: I will turn off printer when not printing
fields.name: Printer off

fields.description:
<center>![Stairwell looking down](/site_media/media/gblocks/stairwell.jpg)</center>

Commit to using the stairs instead of elevators during your day, whenever that is feasible. Elevators use electricity, so by using the stairs you will save some energy. Also, using the stairs is good exercise!
fields.title: I will use stairs instead of elevator
fields.name: Use stairs

fields.depends_on_text: Complete either Climate change video activity or Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description:
<center>![Lid of a recycling bin](/site_media/media/gblocks/recycling-can-lid.jpg)</center>

Commit to recycling all (recyclable) beverage containers at one of the recycling bins on campus or around town. Making things from recycled materials generally costs less and uses less energy than making them from raw materials.
fields.title: I will recycle all beverage containers
fields.name: Recycle cans

fields.description:
<center>![Picture of 3 people in a car](/site_media/media/gblocks/carpool.jpg)</center>

Commit to not driving in a car by yourself. Try riding the bus, riding a bike, walking, driving a moped, or using a vehicle with 3+ occupants instead. Transportation fuel is a major use of energy and it generates a lot of greenhouse gases, so traveling more efficiently saves energy and the planet.
fields.title: I won't drive alone
fields.name: Car pool

fields.description: Commit to taking public transportation at least once in the commitment period. [TheBus](http://thebus.org/) has a great website that will help you plan trips, and tell you when the next bus will arrive based on GPS location!
fields.title: I will take public transportation
fields.name: Take bus

fields.description: Commit to using your TV (watching shows, movies, playing games) for not more than 1 hour per day. Widescreen TVs use a lot of electricity, so putting a limit on how much you use them will reduce your electricity use.
fields.title: I will limit my TV use to 1 hour a day
fields.name: limit TV

fields.depends_on_text: Complete either Climate change video activity or Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to always washing full loads of laundry. Washing less than a full load is less efficient, leading to more electricity and hot water being used per piece of laundry washed.
fields.title: I will wash only full loads of laundry
fields.name: Full load laundry

fields.description:
<center>![Kukui Cup button](/site_media/media/gblocks/button2_1.png)</center>

Commit to displaying your Kukui Cup button (on your clothes, your bag, wherever) every day during the commitment period. Displaying your button will help spread awareness about the competition, and remind others to get involved.
fields.title: I will display my Kukui Cup button every day
fields.name: Display Button

fields.description: Commit to walking to any destination less than one mile away. Walking saves energy, costs nothing, and is good exercise.
fields.title: I will walk to destinations less than one mile away
fields.name: Walk < 1 mi

fields.depends_on_text: Complete either Climate change video activity or Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to washing your laundry in cold water instead of warm or hot water. There are now detergents designed to be used in cold water, and it takes lots of energy to heat water up. By using cold water, you will be saving energy.
fields.title: I will wash my laundry in cold water
fields.name: Cold laundry

fields.depends_on_text: Complete either Climate change video activity or Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to measuring the length of your shower with a watch or phone, and reducing the time by 1 minute. Clean water is a valuable resource that shouldn't be wasted. Also pumping water from the ground into a building, heating it, and then treating the used water takes energy, so reducing the amount of water used saves energy.
fields.title: I will reduce my shower time by 1 minute
fields.name: Shorter shower

fields.description: Commit to turning off your computer/TV/game console and doing something that doesn't require electricity instead. There are many things you can do both on and off campus that don't require electricity, go find them!
fields.title: I will do something 'unplugged' every day
fields.name: Go unplugged

fields.depends_on_text: Complete Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to bringing and using reuseable bags when shopping instead of the paper or plastic ones offered by stores. Making disposable bags requires energy, and often the bags end up in our landfills or worse yet they blow away into the ocean. Using a reusable bag saves energy and keeps trash out of our landfills.
fields.title: I will bring reusable bags when shopping
fields.name: Resuable bag

fields.depends_on_text: Complete Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to not eating any meat (beef, pork, chicken, fish, shellfish, etc) during the commitment period. Producing meat (beef in particular) uses a great deal of energy, and produces a great deal of greenhouse gasses. A vegetarian diet uses less energy and emits less greenhouse gas. There are many of vegetarian food options around Honolulu, try them out!
fields.title: I will not eat meat
fields.name: No meat

fields.description:
This is an opportunity to really explore how Hawaii handles its opala in more depth. Pick one of the activities below and go do it! Note that these activities will require significantly more effort than normal activities, but they are also worth more points. This task is worth a variable number of points, so the more effort and the higher quality of your result, the more points you will receive.

You can also do this activity with one or more friends to get the **social bonus** points.

  * Make a YouTube video about opala
  * Write a letter to the editor about opala
  * Write a song about issues related to Hawaii's opala
  * Start a blog about opala issues
  * Or something else awesome!
fields.title: Advanced opala activity
fields.name: Advanced opala

fields.description:
Check out this video called Trash is Treasure and maybe change your thinking about trash

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/uMxeWJgFLhQ?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/uMxeWJgFLhQ?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch Trash is Treasure video
fields.name: Trash video

fields.description:
<center>![Go Low icon](/site_media/static/css/default/images/icon-go-low-lg.jpg)</center>

One important aspect of the Kukui Cup is the Daily Energy Goal Game, which can be found on the [Go Low](/energy) page. Every lounge is assigned a daily energy goal that represents a 5% reduction in electricity use from what the lounge was using before the competition. The Energy Goal Game shows how much energy your lounge has used so far today, and how that compares to the energy goal. The game also shows some activities that might be helpful in getting your lounge to reduce its energy use.

For this activity, you will check out the [Go Low](/energy) page. Read the page over, and come back to here and report three things: is your lounge above or below the energy goal, by how much, and name one activity that might help your lounge conserve energy.
fields.title: Examine your team's energy use
fields.name: Check energy

fields.depends_on_text: Complete 2 activities in Moving On category
fields.description:
This is an opportunity to really explore the issue of transportation in Hawaii in more depth. Pick one of the activities below and go do it! Note that these activities will require significantly more effort than normal activities, but they are also worth more points. This task is worth a variable number of points, so the more effort and the higher quality of your result, the more points you will receive.

You can also do this activity with one or more friends to get the **social bonus** points.

  * Make a YouTube video about transportation
  * Write a letter to the editor about transportation
  * Write a song about issues related to Hawaii's transportation issues
  * Start a blog about transportation issues
  * Or something else awesome!
fields.title: Advanced transportation activity
fields.name: Advanced transport

fields.description:
<center>![shower head with water coming out](/site_media/media/gblocks/shower-head.jpg)</center>

Figure out how much water is used by the showers in your home. To do this, you will need a large container with a known volume (like a water bottle or bucket) that you can fill in the shower, and a clock of some type (like your watch or cell phone). Make sure to not get your clock wet if it isn't waterproof!

Hold the container up to the shower head, turn on the shower faucet to the level you use normally when showering, and note the time on the clock (or use a stopwatch). Watch the container fill, and note the time when it is completely full of water.

Now you know the volume of water that the shower put out, and the amount of time it was running. From these two values, you can compute the flow rate of your shower by dividing the volume by the number of seconds it took to fill. For example, if you filled a 1 gallon bucket and it took 30 seconds, then the flow rate is 2 gallons per minute.

As you will see, water comes out of shower heads pretty fast, which is why it is important to turn off the water when you aren't actively using it, like while soaping up.
fields.title: Measure shower water flow
fields.name: Shower flow

fields.description:
Watch this video that provides some hints on how to get the most out of the Kukui Cup

<object width="471" height="298"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/qN-OxaX9enI?version=3&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/qN-OxaX9enI?version=3&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="471" height="298" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch video "Secrets of the Kukui Cup Masters"
fields.name: Cup Secrets

fields.depends_on_text: Complete 3 squares from the Get Started column
fields.description:
**Advanced Activity**

An important part of the Kukui Cup is making the residents of Hale Aloha aware of the competition and how they can get involved. We've got some ideas, but we'd like to hear your ideas. Try to come up with some really innovative ways for us to promote the Kukui Cup. This activity is worth a variable number of points, depending on how awesome your ideas are!
fields.title: Come up with innovative ideas for promoting the Kukui Cup
fields.name: Promotion ideas

fields.depends_on_text: Complete either Climate change video activity or Trash is Treasure video activity
fields.description: Commit to always waiting until the dishwasher is full before running it. Washing less than a full load is less efficient, leading to more electricity and hot water being used per dish washed.
fields.title: I will wash only full loads of dishes
fields.name: Full dishwasher

fields.description:
Watch this video about the ways we use energy to generate light.

<object width="471" height="295"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/ZsgmnCxzHao?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/ZsgmnCxzHao?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="471" height="295" wmode="opaque"></embed></object>
fields.title: Watch video about Lighting
fields.name: Lighting video

fields.description:
Watch this video that talks about how we generate our energy in Hawaii right now, and how that differs from the mainland US.

fields.admin_comment: Your answer, 175W, indicates power, not energy.   Watch the video to learn how much power a single solar panel can generate and how many hours of the day it can generate it.  Multiply the two together to get the energy (Wh) for a single day.

Letter to the editor:
from	Y Nagashima kuishinbo@gmail.com
to	letters@staradvertiser.com
date	Sun, Aug 14, 2011 at 2:23 PM
subject	Editor letter (lighting, advance activity)
mailed-by	gmail.com
hide details 2:23 PM (0 minutes ago)

Dear Editor:

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world, " said Margaret Mead, an American anthropologist. It is exactly this type of attitude and commitment that drives a small research group at the University of Hawaii to study how best to engage the young generation to be the stewards of our state's energy resources. 

Entitled the Kukui Cup, UH Computer Science Department Professor, Philip Johnson, has organized a dormitory energy conservation challenge with his researchers for first year students at the Hale Aloha dormitory, set to start in October 2011. They are encouraged to declare specific personal commitments, such as "turn off the lights when you leave the room" and win "kukui points". Another activity calls for students to swap out an incandescent light bulb with a compact florescent light (CFL), which uses less than 1/4 of the incandescent bulbs. It's a simple act that can cut significant energy use.

Blue Planet Foundation has organized student workers to swap out every incandescent bulbs with CFLs. What if each one of us spend the next coffee break swapping out any incandescent bulbs with CFLs at work? What if all State and Local Government in their offices, facilities and in schools, eradicated any traces of the incandescent bulbs?

Some may not share Dr. Mead's optimism for individuals bringing about a larger change. But for the State Government is already committed to the Clean Energy Initiative (conservation goal of 30% by 2030), so we must do our part as individuals, as Dr. Mead concluded her quote, "Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has".

Yuka Nagashima

(808) 226-1338 (cell)
PV panels supply power to home and push excess to the grid.  When home needs additional power, it is provided from the grid.
we're below by 4kWh.  We can conserve energy by setting our computers to sleep after 20 minutes of inactivity.

At time, an appliance that is turned off still is drawing a little bit of power called a "phantom load."

Laptop-30 watts (on) 0 watts (off)
Cell Phone - 7.5 watts (on) 0 watts (off)
Microwave - 900 watts (on) 4 watts (off)
T.V. - 350 watts (on) 0 watts (off)
DVD Player - 134 watts (on) 1.8 watts (off)

In order to to reach out to the students you need to approach them from all different angles.  

1.  Have a launch party that kicks off the whole thing.  Free food, drinks and ice cream.  Maybe even kick it off at the welcome back concert.
2.  Set the incoming freshman up with a few upper classmen dormers who can take them under their wing and work with them in teams!  Lots of collateral benefits also.
3.  Create and promote a FUN challenge as the first challenge.  Maybe have a scavenger hunt around the dorms for some cool prizes.
4.  Create a challenge to see who can recruit the most new players.  New players that sign up (whether they are in or out of their lounge) can win non-kukui point prizes.

The energy choices that we make today will affect every aspect of our lives tomorrow.  Gas prices, food prices, cost of living, energy security and environmental quality will all be affected.  But, we need to become educated and know all the pros and cons of our decisions as we move forward.  We cannot rely on mainland solutions to fix our problems here in Hawaii.  We need to come up with unique solutions for our unique island setting, while still maintaining integrity in our decisions.  Some solutions will be appropriate in certain areas and conditions and some will not.
We have all the renewable sources of energy available to us in the islands to become 100% energy independent

I submitted a letter to the editor- see below:

As a faithful reader of your newspaper, I fail to understand why your editorial staff and newspaper in general is not dedicating more column inches to the issue of renewable energy and conversion of our state away from the use of oil to generate electricity.  The continued use of oil to generate electricity puts our state in a more and more precarious economic position that is subject to the whims of world markets outside our control.  The Star-Advertiser, as the number one daily newspaper in the state, has an obligation to its readers and the people of Hawaii to do more to amplify and educate the public about the seriousness of this problem in order to focus all our energy on a solution.  Please provide more leadership on this important issue.
Energy choices now impact the future
small inefficient grids (also dependent on high cost material - oil)
